awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  P2C2--isotope-enabled TRAnsient Climate Evolution of the last 21,000 years (iTRACE21)----Understanding Deglacial Climate/Isotope Changes Using iCESM
awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates the mechanisms of climate changes during the last deglaciation (21,000 to 11,000 years ago) using a state-of-the-art isotope-enabled Earth System Model (ESM). The major scientific questions to be addressed in this project are: (1) What are the relationships between the isotopic composition of water and climate changes over the globe? (2) How does the climate system respond to changing climate forcings of the last deglaciation, and what is the contribution from each forcing: insolation, atmospheric greenhouse gases, continental ice sheets, and meltwater? The simulations will allow the study of the continuous evolution and abrupt changes of climate from interannual to orbital time scales. The type of transient simulation marks a transformative breakthrough in model-data comparison, allowing for direct data and model time series comparisons, and will have a significant impact on future paleoclimate studies using both models and observations. The proposed simulations will have a ground breaking impact on research in the paleoclimate community, providing model data for a number of other community projects. It will lay a foundation for a systematic test of future generations of ESMs with coupled cryosphere and biogeochemical models. 

Specifically, the new version of NCAR's community ESM (CESM), enabled with water isotope tracers, will be run in fully-coupled mode for the period 21,000 to 11,000 years ago. The main simulation will be forced by prescribed changes in insolation, atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, continental ice sheets, sea level, and meltwater, while sensitivity simulations will investigate the effect of the different forcings separately. This simulation will be run at a higher resolution (2 degrees in the atmosphere and 1 degree in the ocean) than the previous generation transient model run with CCSM3 (3 degrees). Furthermore, stable water isotope tracers have been included in the atmosphere, land-surface, ocean, and sea-ice models and will be tested first for the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, 21,000 years ago) and present climate time slices before being run in transient mode for the last deglaciation. One central task of the proposed transient simulations is to explore a new paradigm of model-data comparison in close collaboration with the data community, focusing on direct time series comparisons of isotopes. The simulation of isotope time series will improve paleoclimate model-data comparison significantly, because it will reduce the uncertainties arising from both the inference of isotopes and the absolute chronology of the proxy records. The project will provide the basis for graduate research for students from the University of Wisconsin and Oregon State University.

OUTCOME

 

Prog Mgr:      David J. Verardo

PIs:                Zhengyu Liu, Bette Otto-Bliesner, Peter Clark

 

A Collaborative Proposal:

 

Collaborative Proposal:

Isotope-enabled Transient Climate Evolution of the last 21,000 years  (iTRACE)

----Understanding Deglacial Climate/Isotope Changes using iCESM

(Award Number: AGS-1810682/ 1401803/ 1401802)

OSU Award: 60062118

Proposal Period: 2014-2017, 1st No Cost Extension to 2018,

2nd No Cost Extension to 2019 

 

Zhengyu Liu (AGS-1810682)

Department of Geography, Ohio State University

Tel: 614/292-7948,  Email: liu.7022@osu.edu

 

Bette Otto-Bliesner (AGS-1401803)

Climate and Global Dynamics Division, National Center for Atmospheric Research

Tel: 303/497-1723, Fax: 303/497-1348, Email: ottobli@ucar.edu

 

Peter Clark (AGS-1401802)

Dept. of Geosciences, Oregon State University

Tel: 541/737-1247, Email: clarkp@onid.orst.edu

 

 

 

The overall goal of the project is to test the water isotope-enabled version of CESM against paleo-observations and to improve our understanding of the mechanisms for the climate/isotope evolution of the last 21 kyr in light of direct model/data comparisons of isotope proxies. With a close collaboration among Ohio State University, NCAR and Oregon State University, we have successfully completed the iTRACE21 project (isotope enabled Transient Climate Evolution of the last 21,000 years). We have made several major achievements. First, after overcoming many unexpected difficulties, we have finally completed the first synchronously coupled water isotope enabled CGCM simulation of the climate evolution of the last deglaciation (21,000 – 11,000 years in the iCESM (iTRACE). To help shed light on the mechanism of the isotope-climate evolution, we have also completed a full set of single forcing transient simulations forced by the continental ice sheet (and ocean bathymetry) (ICE), and additionally the orbital forcing (ICE+ORB), greenhouse gas forcing (ICE+ORB+GHG), on the last of which a realistic meltwater history is imposed to generate the iTRACE simulation. Our preliminary analysis shows that iTRACE simulation is able to simulate the evolution of several major benchmarks of water isotope-climate proxies successfully. Therefore, our iTRACE simulations may provide potentially an excellent benchmark for model-data comparison and for the understanding of deglaciation isotope-climate evolution for the community, as we did previously in TRACE21. We are in the process of post-processing model data for publication and dissimilation to the community.

 

Furthermore, in preparation of our study of the iTRACE simulations, we have performed extensive studies and model-data comparison in understanding the mechanism of isotope and climate changes since the LGM as well as some fundamental knowledge on climate dynamics. These works range from deep water formation, AMOC instability, d18O response mechanism to global heat transport theory.  Two highlights are described briefly below.

 

δ18O -Temperature relation: The slope equation.  We have also examined the LGM and PI runs of the current iCESM for the temporal slope equation. 

 

The equation suggests that the temporal slope is usually smaller than the spatial slope in the extratropics mainly because of the polar amplification feature in global climate change, such that the response in local temperature at high-latitudes is usually greater than that in the total equivalent source temperature. Two further progresses have been made in the last year, both supporting the original proposal. First, we analyzed the LGM and PI experiment in the newly developed iCESM. It is interesting that, in spite of somewhat different spatial slopes in the two models, the temporal slope is always shallower than the spatial slope in both hemispheres. This is exactly what is predicted from the polar amplification temperature response pattern in both models based on the slope equation. Second, we performed tagging experiments to search for the source temperature explicitly in both iCAM3 and iCESM. Our results show largely consistent results as the previous “backward” test, providing a further support for the slope equation.

Deglacial asynchronous warming of deep Atlantic: Changes in deep Atlantic water masses during the last deglaciation may have released the accumulated deep-ocean carbon and caused the early deglacial increase of the atmospheric CO2. However, these changes are poorly constrained by δ18O of benthic foraminiferal calcite (δ18Oc), resulting in controversy on the relative contributions of northern and southern deep-water sources and their role in the carbon cycle. Here we use an isotope-enabled ocean general circulation model under realistic transient climate forcing to provide a dynamic framework for understanding deglacial δ18Oc signals. Model results suggest that input from both northern and southern sources into the ocean interior decreased in response to North Atlantic freshwater forcing early during the last deglaciation. The North Atlantic at 3000 m warmed by 1.4°C due to enhanced downward diffusive heat transport, while the deep Southern Ocean temperatures remained mostly unchanged. This asynchronous warming, rather than changes in the relative contribution of water mass sources as previously assumed, should be considered as the main cause of the observed δ18Oc phase differences.
